candidates.title: Update to tari_utils 0.1.2 and send_tari arg parsing
candidates.body:
The send_tari command was causing a thread panic if an emoji id was
used. In refactoring the parsing logic, it was discovered that the
problem lay with `from_hex` in the tari_utilities crate.

The crate was patched with a fix and bumped to 0.1.2.

The send_tari command now works with both hex and emoji pubkeys.

candidates.title: Remove R2D2 for Sqlite from Wallet
candidates.body:
## Description
R2D2 was added to provide thread safety for the Async wallet services with the thought that in the future we might require a pool of connections but after testing we are having problems with Segmentation Faults on Android coming from the R2D2 thread pool.

So this PR removes the threadpool in favour of a single SqliteConnection maintained behind a Arc<Mutex<>>. This is a much simpler arrangement and will hopefully be more stable on mobile platforms.

I also moved the wallet logging to being initialized in the Wallet FFI so that logging starts as early as possible.

## How Has This Been Tested?
Updated existing tests

candidates.title: Detect failure and reestablish tor control connection + tor events
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
If the tor server is restarted (for whatever reason), the hidden service
would cease to exist on the tor network making it impossible for clients
to connect into the node until the node is restarted.

This PR fixes this by adding a controller that is responsible for tor
hidden service reliability. If the tor control server disconnects, the 
controller will attempt to reconnect every 5 seconds until either 
it succeeds or is shut down. On success, clients will be able once 
more to connect to the node's hidden service.

Additionally, the TorControlClient now has the ability to subscribe to
events emitted by the tor control server and publish those on a tokio
broadcast channel. This could be useful down-the-line for determining
network availability/bandwidth usage etc.

This implementation required that:
1. The tor control connection is monitored in it's own task
1. Events and response text is split into seperate streams
1. The hidden service is immediately recovered once a connection is
   reestablished.
1. The event stream is preserved when reestablishing connections to tor
1. The SETEVENTS command is supported


## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->
Closes #1497 

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
More extensive tests needed - existing control client tests pass, base node tor disconnect/reconnect works

candidates.title: Fix for mobile wallet discovery + "memorynet"
candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
The DHT did not propagate private discovery messages to wallets because
they do not have the `MESSAGE_PROPAGATION` feature.

This PR changes the behaviour of the DHT to include wallets in
discovery propagation messages. Internally, the Forward step of the DHT pipeline 
has a special case that will propagate discovery messages to wallets. The closest peer selection 
has been adjusted to allow the caller to specify the PeerFeatures of the closest nodes to target by using the `neighbours_with_features` call.
_NOTE:_ because those nodes will not propagate the message further, the selection ensures 
that a minimum number of propagation nodes are always selected   

This PR also includes a new example called "memorynet". `memorynet`, as
the name suggests, is a small in-memory DHT network consisting of a
number of "base nodes" and "wallets" (all that differs is their feature
flags).

The following happens when running `memorynet`:
1. A single "seed node", `NUM_NODES` "base nodes" and `NUM_WALLETS` "wallets" are generated and started.
1. All "base nodes" join the network via the "seed node"
1. All "wallets" join the network via a random "base node"
1. The first "wallet" in the list attempts to discover the last "wallet" in the list
1. The result of the discovery is printed and the network is shut down

The example can be run with this command:
`RUST_LOG=trace cargo run --example memorynet 2> /tmp/debug.log`

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here. -->

Closes #1204 

The _memorynet_ example provides clean and easy to read output that allows you to easily see what is happening between a network of nodes. Each generated node is assigned a name that is used in stdout output. Normal internal logs are logged to stderr and can be switched on using the `RUST_LOG` environment variable.

```text
----------------------------------------------------------
Bringing up virtual network consisting of a seed node, 15 nodes and 2 wallets
----------------------------------------------------------

Node 'Bob' is joining the network via the seed node 'Alice'
EVENT: 'Bob (1d79bcc44d814748)' connected to 'Alice (1dc460f5fe4e3675)'
EVENT: 'Alice (1dc460f5fe4e3675)' got inbound connection from 'Bob (1d79bcc44d814748)'

Node 'Carol' is joining the network via the seed node 'Alice'
EVENT: 'Carol (dea46505688b5ac7)' connected to 'Alice (1dc460f5fe4e3675)'
EVENT: 'Alice (1dc460f5fe4e3675)' got inbound connection from 'Carol (dea46505688b5ac7)'

Node 'Charlie' is joining the network via the seed node 'Alice'
EVENT: 'Charlie (d4eaac42550edbd9)' connected to 'Alice (1dc460f5fe4e3675)'
EVENT: 'Alice (1dc460f5fe4e3675)' got inbound connection from 'Charlie (d4eaac42550edbd9)'
EVENT: 'Bob (1d79bcc44d814748)' connected to 'Carol (dea46505688b5ac7)'
EVENT: 'Carol (dea46505688b5ac7)' got inbound connection from 'Bob (1d79bcc44d814748)'
(snip...)
----------------------------------------------------------
Discovery is done.
----------------------------------------------------------

⚡️🎉😎 'Vanna' discovered peer 'Plod (7bb7b1d55953e391)' ([7bb7b1d55953e391] PK=88aed2306b39d4c4659b6a41d98199c5a8acb48155ba1e2fa6c356edece7c251 Features=NONE | COMMUNICATION_CLIENT) in 11014ms
(snip...)
```

## How Has This Been Tested?
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes. -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
_memorynet_ is the primary test of these changes. It has shown that discovery messages do not always make it through and will provide an excellent testbed for DHT reliability.

candidates.body:
<!--- Provide a general summary of your changes in the Title above -->

## Description
- Target dependency `[target.'cfg(not(windows))'.dev-dependencies.cursive]` added to the `p2p/Cargo.toml` file to only include Cursive as a dependency if the target is not Windows.
- Example `pingpong.rs` changed to exclude all code if the target is not Windows.
- In conjuction with @sdbondi 

## Motivation and Context
Cursive is not supported on Windows, exclude its build & test when running `test --all-features`

## How Has This Been Tested?
- `cargo test --package=tari_p2p --all-features` on Windows 10 and Linux Ubuntu, build and test works on both operating systems

- `cargo run --example pingpong` on Linux Ubuntu:
```
error: The following required arguments were not provided:
```

candidates.title: 33 character emoji ids

Docs have also been improved.
